name: Þorlákshöfn
description:
Þorlákshöfn is a coastal town in South Iceland, located on the Reykjanes Peninsula approximately 45 kilometers southeast of Reykjavík. Named after Saint Þorlákur, Iceland's only Catholic-era saint, this town of about 1,700 residents serves as an important fishing port and ferry terminal. The town's development accelerated in the 20th century as it became a major fishing center, with fish processing remaining central to the local economy. Þorlákshöfn also serves as the mainland port for the ferry service to the Westman Islands (Vestmannaeyjar), making it a transit point for travelers heading to this fascinating offshore archipelago. The town's harbor is one of the best on Iceland's southern coast, providing shelter from the fierce Atlantic storms that regularly batter this exposed coastline.

The town's layout reflects its 20th-century development, with functional architecture and a grid-like street pattern designed for efficiency rather than aesthetics. However, Þorlákshöfn has its own character and serves as an authentic example of an Icelandic working fishing town. The community includes all essential services—schools, swimming pool, shops, restaurants, and accommodations—making it a self-sufficient settlement. The town's swimming pool is excellent and popular with both locals and visitors, featuring multiple pools and hot tubs with ocean views. The harbor area is interesting to explore, with working fishing boats, processing facilities, and the ferry terminal providing insight into Iceland's maritime industries. The town also has a small museum dedicated to local history and the fishing industry.

For visitors, Þorlákshöfn serves primarily as a gateway to the Westman Islands, with the ferry (Herjólfur) departing regularly. However, the town itself deserves more than just a rushed pre-ferry visit. The surrounding area offers scenic coastal walks, birdwatching opportunities, and geological features including lava fields and interesting rock formations. The town provides an affordable alternative to staying in Reykjavík, with lower accommodation prices and easy access to South Coast attractions. Local restaurants serve excellent fresh seafood, often directly from the day's catch. The swimming pool offers relaxation and a chance to experience local culture. Þorlákshöfn represents everyday Iceland—a working town where people make their living from the sea, maintain strong community bonds, and welcome visitors who take time to look beyond Iceland's famous natural attractions.
opening_hours: Town accessible year-round. Ferry to Westman Islands operates daily (check schedule). Shops and services have varying hours.
